docs.lead_paragraph: OTHER fathers taught their sons how to throw curveballs. Leonard Rivkin's taught him to read X-rays. And Mr. Rivkin knew what an articular fracture was before he could roller skate. Mr. Rivkin's father, Hyman Rivkin, was a physician in Far Rockaway. He believed medicine was more than just a noble profession. It was the only profession. ''I ended up becoming a lawyer through pre-med,'' Mr. Rivkin, 75, said recently. ''Fathers who are doctors want their sons to be doctors. I was in pre-med until I decided I didn't like it. I couldn't stand chemistry.''

headline.main: Long Island Journal; When Medicine's Loss Is the Law's Gain

docs.abstract: Long Island Journal; Leonard Rivkin recalls founding of his law firm, Rivkin Radler & Kremer, fifty years ago; photo; Yvonne Pena and Dorothy Tripp are among honorees at inaugural Long Island's 50 Top Women awards dinner (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: ITALY'S LAKES Italiatour, the tour division of Alitalia, has packages to the lake district of northern Italy that start at $1,199 a person, double occupancy, from New York, Newark or Boston. The price includes round-trip flights to Milan, seven nights at the Hotel Metropole in Bellaggio, with service charges and V.A.T., breakfast and dinner daily and seven-day rental of a small manual-transmission car with insurance and unlimited mileage. Travel must be completed by June 14. From Friday through May 31, the company also has a package to Tuscany including air fare from New York, Newark or Boston to Florence or Pisa, six hotel nights and a six-day car rental starting at $1,099 a person at the Hotel Leon Bianco in San Gimignano. Information and reservations: (800) 845-3365. WEEKEND IN MANHATTAN The Regal U.N. Plaza Hotel has a weekend ''Top of the World'' rate of $179 a room on Friday and Saturday through May 31 that includes car service to the theater district or Fifth Avenue shopping and either a full American breakfast for two or a two-for-one Champagne and lobster brunch on Sundays (except Easter) for $56 plus tax and tip. The room tax of 13 1/4 percent plus $2 is extra. Arrangements for the car service must be made the night before.

docs.lead_paragraph: THE health care community recognized the need for hospice care in adults about 30 years ago, but is slower in its thinking about end-of-life care for children. Amy S. Kuhner, a pastoral counselor with a master's degree from Yale Divinity School, said she believed that dying children belong in a place of their own. She said England has 19 children's hospices; the United States has not one. For the past four years, Ms. Kuhner has been working toward opening Sunshine House, a center that would provide care for children with life-threatening illnesses. It would offer care for seriously ill children whose families need a break as well as hospice care. It would be the first center of its kind exclusively for children in Connecticut.

headline.main: The Fight for a Home for Ailing Children

docs.abstract: Amy S Kuhner discusses her campaign to open Sunshine House, center to care for children with life-threatening diseases; Connecticut Legislature has enacted law enabling center to open, and site is being sought; her photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Technology stocks remained the market victors in the first quarter, but old standbys like Intel seemed to be eclipsing Internet darlings by the end. In an appropriately discordant finish to a wild and crazy quarter, major market indexes moved in opposite directions once again yesterday. The Dow Jones industrial average was up solidly for most of the session, but reversed course late in the day to close at 10,921.92, down 58.33 points, or 0.5 percent. Computer programs related to end-of-quarter portfolio shuffling were cited by market participants.

headline.main: Nasdaq Posts Its First Gain Of the Week

docs.abstract: Dow Jones industrial average closes at 10,921.92, down 58.33 points, or 0.5 percent; Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rises 10.66 points, or 0.7 percent, to 1,498.58; Nasdaq composite index rallies for first time in week, gaining 114.94 points, or 2.6 percent, to 4,572.83; graph on Dow Jones industrial average; charts on stocks with large price percentage gains and losses and common stocks with largest gains and declines in percentage terms in first quarter of 2000, as calculated by Associated Press (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The Policy Management Systems Corporation, a maker of insurance and financial services software, said late on Thursday that it had agreed to sell almost all of the company to a New York investment firm. The firm, Welsh Carson Anderson & Stowe will spend $604 million to buy 75 percent to 93 percent of the company, based in Blythewood, S.C. The offer is for $14 a share. On the New York Stock Exchange, the shares were up $3.25 each, or 37 percent, at $12. The company's stock traded at more than $50 last year. Welsh Carson specializes in buying stock of health care and information management companies.

headline.main: POLICY MANAGEMENT SYSTEMS AGREES TO ITS SALE

docs.abstract: Welsh Carson Anderson & Stowe will spend $604 million to buy 75 percent to 93 percent of Policy Management Systems Corp (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Conseco Inc., the once highflying insurance company that stumbled badly when it diversified into consumer lending, said yesterday that it would sell the lending operation, the former Green Tree Finance, which it bought in 1998 for stock worth $7.6 billion. It will take a write-off of at least $350 million after taxes. ''The pain threshold for our shareholders was just too great,'' said Stephen H. Hilbert, Conseco's chairman and chief executive, during a combative conference call with analysts, who seemed surprised at the company's second abrupt change of strategy within four months.

headline.main: Conseco to Sell Loan Unit, Giving Up Brief Effort to Diversify

docs.abstract: Conseco Inc, once highflying insurance company that stumbled badly when it diversified into consumer lending, says it will sell lending operation, former Green Tree Finance, which it bought in 1998 for stock worth $7.6 billion; it will take write-off of at least $350 million after taxes; chairman-chief executive Stephen H Hilbert, during combative conference call with analysts, says company will focus on life and health insurance, and pledges that it will not diversify again; Hilbert, who in past has frequently forecast profits, declines to do so now (M)
